Baltimore Friday, February 16, 1897.


r We wish that every friend Of this Journal should
dertand and that they would have the kindness to make
known, that any who will procure four subscribers
and remit their $780, will send the American Farmer
without chargeor any who will procure fus subscr

will be guaranteed by the Editor.


The American Farmer is published wecky-about one
half four pages, devoted to practical Agricultural the
remainder to Internal improvements Rural and Domestic
Economy selections for housekeepers and female readers
and Natural History and Rural Sports. minute ndexs
and title psge to the whole volume, is published and
forwarded with the last number single number ul be
any who may desire to see specimen Of the
publication. To all editors who will give the above
Insertions shall feel much indebted, and will
gladly reciprocate their kindness.

and territory and is written for by many of the most
distinguished practical farmers in the Union.

INTERNAL IMPROVEMENTS.


OF the 1o4 votes given in The fifteen States north
Of the Potomac and Ohio, OIL the appropriation to

and two others. OF the "a votes given in the nine
States south of the Ohio and Potomac, only "a were
in favor Of the appropriation, and Of these, IL were
in favor of the administration.


On the appropriation of fifty thousand dollars or
the preservation and repair OF the Cumberland road,
the exhibits similar result and what is worth
volume OF comments is, the fact that on this occa-
sion, the Tennessee members who travel on this
road. to and from Congress, voted unanimously
against the appropriation Of $4,000 dollars, and those
from Massachusetts,, who probably have never seen
the road and, perhaps, never will, voted eight for,
and only three against it, and one Of these Jackso
nian !! = What will the people Of the west and
the friends OF internal improvement think Of thisP
Comment is unnecessary. Let the public examine
these things, and decide whether this administration
is be prosrated for the purpose Of putting men in
power who are hostile 10 these measures.

Mr.. Drtght after leave obtained, moved the con-

yesterdays


Resolved, That the Secretary Of the Treasury
be directed TO inform this House whether the ac-
counts of John Quincy Adams, Envoy Extraordina
ry and Minister Plenipotentary to St. Petersburgh,
Client, and London, contained any charge made by
him for travelling back from Client to St. Peters

Client, Paris, and Havre, seeking a passage to the

to transmit to this House copy Of the account Of
said Minister rendered by him to the Department,
covering charge Tor one thousand dollars paid his
Secretary; and the travelling expenses OF his fami
ly from ST. Petersburgh to Paris"
The motion prevailed--ayes rs. Noes IS,

| ..Also, what Sum was received by him from the

| if any, what, sum has been received by any public

the head Of contingencies and when and to whom
such charge was first allowed.


4 Mr.. Di0ght said, he could not consent to adopt.
as his own the amendment of his resolution, offered
by the gentleman from Pennsylvania He had, him.
self specific object in view and he feared that the
amendment Of the gentleman, SO lar from enabling

at this period OF The Session. prevent the correction

His object, he confessed, by the resolution he had

tersburgh had, as the gentleman asserted, made q
charge for the expenses Of journey from Ghent
10 ST. Petersburgh, which journey was confessedly
never made by that Minister. He had not him
self owing to The pressure Of business in the House
al that time, heard the remarks OF the gentleman,
bot upon observing them in the report OF the sue

strong mpr essicn, which required an investigation
into facts affecting The reputation oil distinguished
; public servant.

ban Observer Of Philadelphia, who is application

The Greek Fund-A sermon preached on Monday
evening last, by the Rev Mr. BEDELL in ST. Paus Church.
Philadelphia, in aid of the Greek Fund.- The collection
whole collected in that city for the Greeks up
wards of thousand dollars. The collections in the city
Of New York have been still greater.


We would call the attention of the Editor Of the vir-
gna jackson Republican, Mr.. Harkers former opinion
Of Gen Jackson The Republican values partisans but
those who have always been aptoMe-hu6 men. We
wish undeceive him in the opinion he has formed Of the
Corporal.


We have recently published Mr.. Harksr's opin-
ion of Gen. Jackson, expressed by him 10 his
Gazette before the la.t Presidential election. Mr..
Halker notices our publication, in his paper OF
Tuesday, and in an article under the head Of
!" Consistency," says, near the commencement
We will not say that such an expression was ncv-
er made By US, for VIC do not know at what time or
under what circumstances it is pretended that i,
was made !; but we will say that We have no recol-
lection of having used the language in the manner
attributed to us; and We will say, moreover, tina,
| VIC 90 NOT tniDk VIC SsCl uu ~ usG IL a. so
events" Continues he, "a candid and honorable
opponent would have pointed to the time when we
so expressed ourselves" This we had always in
tended 10 do But it seems Mr.. Harker has anti
cpated u.s. for before he gets to the conclusion OF
his consistent article, he makes discovery OF the
time when he ssed the language which We have
several times quoted as expressive OF his opinion OF
the character Of Gen. Jackson. But he attempts
10 clear himself from the charge Of Inconsistency
krz, ht / for lin m an
once so grossly and unsparngly abused, BY assert
ing that tine passage which have quoted to prove
| his inconsistency was only used in comparison
between the General and Messrs. Clay and Clinton,
and that it does not express the sentiment that he
considered him more Objectionable than Mr.. A
dams. Mr.. Harker, in making use OF such sub
tcrfuge only shows the desperate state OF his case.


We have now before us the Delaware Gazette
Of November 1, 1922, which may be seen at this
Office In that paper, MIR. Harker is noticing the
change which had Just taken place in the proprle
torship Of the Aurora and informs his readers
that VIM. J. Duane, who was to edit the paper
until the new proprietor took possession OF it, has
taken up the subject Of the approaching Presden
ta Election, and in presenting his views on 1t, has
arrayed Messrs Clay, Clinton and Jackson, against
Messrs. Adams, Calhoun, and Crawford" In the
third paragraph following, Mr.. Harker says,
"of all the gentlemen named. Gen. Jackson appear,
to us to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE. That he is
q man of energy, will doubt, but we think that
in chief magistrate of the United States, too much en-
srey i extremely dangerous; AND have seen IN THE
GENERAL such DISREGARD FOR THE INSTITU-
TIONS of the country, such a DISPOSITION 10 place
himself ABOVE ts iarvs, AND such an INCLINATION "a
TRAMpLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS, when
they stood in competition with HIS OWN INTEREST o.
FEELINGS, as should render the citizens Of the United
States vry cautious about placing him in the first office
within their gift


We would not insul, the good understanding o
our readers by attempting to give an explanation
Of Mr.. Harker's meaning in the above language
1t is too plain to need translator.


| But even granting that the extract from the Ga
zeue Of 1922, was employed in the manner in which
he says in his paper Of Tuesday last, it was used
does it at sll affect The language which Mr.. Harker
employed in describing tho character OF Gen. Jack.
son ? By no means. Leaving all comparison with
other men out Of the question, he has declared
him to be man who " disregards the institutions
of his country &c. The revival Of these words
we know, has produced Mr. Harker great deal oI
unea asiness, and made him almost wish that his Ga.
zete had never been filed-and put him into grea.
ouandary as to how to act upon his assertion that
!. an honest man cannot be shamed BY sight Of


what HE HAS SAID on former OCCASION"
From the frequent notices, in the opposition
prints OF the state OF Mr. CrdfGrds hea we are ied 10
suppose that idea is entertained of bringing him
forward again a candidate for the presidency Savan
nah paper of the 20l u states that his health is better
than has been any period since 1928, that his speech
nearly or quite restored and that his whole system is
improving strength" Will Corporal IIarker. who pro


sses know every thing about such matters. inform
whether there is any probability that Gen. Jackson the
man Who he says dsegaid dS the institutions of his
try-paces himself above its laws-and tramples the
rights Of Others" will be given up for Mr.. Cra~ford'

wards of ten thousand dollars The collections in the city
of New York have been still greater.

full articles.headline: LOOK OUT FOR CoUNTERFEITs! 4.
full articles.article:
We have heard of than dozen counterfeit notes.
of the denomination of five dollars the Marine Bank Of
Baltimore having been passed in this Borough this week
They letter in text hand, made payable to NJ Nor
rss dated April 4, 1896, and signed Jo. Bier or Bers,
Cashier, and Hezekiah Waters, President.


We learn from the Philadelphia Press. that notes of the
above description were offered several Exchange Offices
in that city, on Tuesday.

John Binns in his Democratic Press. has lately made
singular political discosure-one which will not redouna
much the credit Of those who have made so much noise
about corruption coalition presses printing by authority
&c. II is this: Stephen Simpson, editor of the late Colum.
ban Observer Of Philadelphia, who is application
the benefit of the insovent laws. is indebted to John H.
Eaon Senator from Tennessee, the friend and biogfapber
of General Jackson the Of $500 1t is added,
that "here subsisted any intimacy between Simpson
and Eaton, till since the establishment Of the Columbian
Observer"

of the denomination of five dollars on the Marine Bank Of
Baltimore, having been passed in this Borough this week
riss dated April A. 1896 and signed Jo. Bier OF Biers,
Cashier, and Hezekiah Waters, President


We learn from the Philadelphia Press that notes Of the
above description offered at several Exchange oces
in that city, on Tuesday.


The Greek Fund-A sermon preached on Monday
evening last, by the Rev Mr. BEDELL in ST. Paus Church.
Philadelphia, in aid of the Greek Fund.- The collection
whole collected in that city for the Greeks up
wards of thousand dollars. The collections in the city
Of New York have been still greater.


We would call the attention of the Editor Of the vir-
gna jackson Republican, Mr.. Harkers former opinion
Of Gen Jackson The Republican values partisans but
those who have always been aptoMe-hu6 men. We
wish undeceive him in the opinion he has formed Of the
Corporal.


We have recently published Mr.. Harksr's opin-
ion of Gen. Jackson, expressed by him 10 his
Gazette before the la.t Presidential election. Mr..
Halker notices our publication, in his paper OF
Tuesday, and in an article under the head Of
!" Consistency," says, near the commencement
We will not say that such an expression was ncv-
er made By US, for VIC do not know at what time or
under what circumstances it is pretended that i,
was made !; but we will say that We have no recol-
lection of having used the language in the manner
attributed to us; and We will say, moreover, tina,
| VIC 90 NOT tniDk VIC SsCl uu ~ usG IL a. so
events" Continues he, "a candid and honorable
opponent would have pointed to the time when we
so expressed ourselves" This we had always in
tended 10 do But it seems Mr.. Harker has anti
cpated u.s. for before he gets to the conclusion OF
his consistent article, he makes discovery OF the
time when he ssed the language which We have
several times quoted as expressive OF his opinion OF
the character Of Gen. Jackson. But he attempts
10 clear himself from the charge Of Inconsistency
krz, ht / for lin m an
once so grossly and unsparngly abused, BY assert
ing that tine passage which have quoted to prove
| his inconsistency was only used in comparison
between the General and Messrs. Clay and Clinton,
and that it does not express the sentiment that he
considered him more Objectionable than Mr.. A
dams. Mr.. Harker, in making use OF such sub
tcrfuge only shows the desperate state OF his case.


We have now before us the Delaware Gazette
Of November 1, 1922, which may be seen at this
Office In that paper, MIR. Harker is noticing the
change which had Just taken place in the proprle
torship Of the Aurora and informs his readers
that VIM. J. Duane, who was to edit the paper
until the new proprietor took possession OF it, has
taken up the subject Of the approaching Presden
ta Election, and in presenting his views on 1t, has
arrayed Messrs Clay, Clinton and Jackson, against
Messrs. Adams, Calhoun, and Crawford" In the
third paragraph following, Mr.. Harker says,
"of all the gentlemen named. Gen. Jackson appear,
to us to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE. That he is
q man of energy, will doubt, but we think that
in chief magistrate of the United States, too much en-
srey i extremely dangerous; AND have seen IN THE
GENERAL such DISREGARD FOR THE INSTITU-
TIONS of the country, such a DISPOSITION 10 place
himself ABOVE ts iarvs, AND such an INCLINATION "a
TRAMpLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS, when
they stood in competition with HIS OWN INTEREST o.
FEELINGS, as should render the citizens Of the United
States vry cautious about placing him in the first office
within their gift


We would not insul, the good understanding o
our readers by attempting to give an explanation
Of Mr.. Harker's meaning in the above language
1t is too plain to need translator.


| But even granting that the extract from the Ga
zeue Of 1922, was employed in the manner in which
he says in his paper Of Tuesday last, it was used
does it at sll affect The language which Mr.. Harker
employed in describing tho character OF Gen. Jack.
son ? By no means. Leaving all comparison with
other men out Of the question, he has declared
him to be man who " disregards the institutions
of his country &c. The revival Of these words
we know, has produced Mr. Harker great deal oI
unea asiness, and made him almost wish that his Ga.
zete had never been filed-and put him into grea.
ouandary as to how to act upon his assertion that
!. an honest man cannot be shamed BY sight Of


what HE HAS SAID on former OCCASION"
From the frequent notices, in the opposition
prints OF the state OF Mr. CrdfGrds hea we are ied 10
suppose that idea is entertained of bringing him
forward again a candidate for the presidency Savan
nah paper of the 20l u states that his health is better
than has been any period since 1928, that his speech
nearly or quite restored and that his whole system is
improving strength" Will Corporal IIarker. who pro


sses know every thing about such matters. inform
whether there is any probability that Gen. Jackson the
man Who he says dsegaid dS the institutions of his
try-paces himself above its laws-and tramples the
rights Of Others" will be given up for Mr.. Cra~ford'

have been added Corporal Harke list in consequence

The Greek Fund-A sermon preached on Monday
evening last by the Rev MIR BEDELL in ST. Paus Church.
Philadelphia, in aid of the Greek Fund. The collection
amounted to three hundred and seventytwo dollars The
whole amount collected in that city for the Greeks, is
wards of ten thousand dollars The collections in the city
of New York have been still greater.

Washington, February ass.-On the publication
Of the documents and testimony connected with the
Report Of the Committee in the Of the Vice
Presidents appeal, Major Vanderenter, chief clerk
in the War Department, was removed from Office.
and Major Charles J. .Nourse was appointed his
successor.
